links.description:
XHTML+RDFa (Extensible Hypertext Markup Language + Resource Description Framework in attributes) is an extended version of the XHTML markup language for supporting RDF through a collection of attributes and processing rules in the form of well-formed XML documents. XHTML+RDFa is one of the techniques used to develop Semantic Web content by embedding rich semantic markup.
Version 1.1 of the language is a superset of XHTML 1.1, integrating the attr...

links.description:
The Linux Security Module (LSM) framework provides a mechanism for
various security checks to be hooked by new kernel extensions. The name
‚Äúmodule‚Äù is a bit of a misnomer since these extensions are not actually
loadable kernel modules. Instead, they are selectable at build-time via
CONFIG_DEFAULT_SECURITY and can be overridden at boot-time via the
"security=..." kernel command line argument, in the case where multiple
LSMs were built into a given...

links.title: A limited role for unforced internal variability in 20th century warming.: Journal of Climate: Early Online Release
links.description: The early 20th century warming (EW; 1910-1945) and the mid-20th century cooling (MC; 1950-1980) have been linked to both, internal variability of the climate system and changes in external radiative forcing. The degree to which either of the two factors contributed to EW and MC, or both, is still debated. Using a two-box impulse response model, we demonstrate that multidecadal ocean variability was unlikely to be the driver of observed changes in...

links.title: Onion Curve: A Space Filling Curve with Near-Optimal Clustering
links.description:
Space filling curves (SFCs) are widely used in the design of indexes for
spatial and temporal data. Clustering is a key metric for an SFC, that measures
how well the curve preserves locality in moving from higher dimensions to a
single dimension. We present the {\em onion curve}, an SFC whose clustering
performance is provably close to optimal for the cube and near-cube shaped
query sets, irrespective of the side length of the query. We show that...
links.original_title: Onion Curve: A Space Filling Curve with Near-Optimal Clustering (2018)

links.title: Space-filling curve - Wikipedia
links.description: In mathematical analysis, a space-filling curve is a curve whose range contains the entire 2-dimensional unit square (or more generally an n-dimensional unit hypercube). Because Giuseppe Peano (1858‚Äì1932) was the first to discover one, space-filling curves in the 2-dimensional plane are sometimes called Peano curves, but that phrase also refers to the Peano curve, the specific example of a space-filling curve found by Peano.

links.title: Convolution - Wikipedia
links.description: In mathematics (in particular, functional analysis) convolution is a mathematical operation on two functions (f and g) to produce a third function that expresses how the shape of one is modified by the other.  The term convolution refers to both the result function and to the process of computing it.  Some features of convolution are similar to cross-correlation: for real-valued functions, of a continuous or discrete variable, it differs from cro...

links.description: Spry was a brand of vegetable shortening produced by Lever Brothers starting in 1936.  It was a competitor for Procter & Gamble's Crisco, and through aggressive marketing through its mascot Aunt Jenny had reached 75 percent of Crisco's market share.  The marketing efforts were phased out in the 1950s, but Aunt Jenny and her quotes like With Spry, we can afford to have cake oftener! have been reprinted.[1]  Though the product is discontinued in mo...

links.title: Lynx (web browser) - Wikipedia
links.description: Lynx is a customizable text-based web browser for use on cursor-addressable character cell terminals.[6][7] As of January 2019[update], it is the oldest web browser still in general use and active development,[8] having started in 1992.

links.title: Oracle PowerBrowser - Wikipedia
links.description: Oracle PowerBrowser was a web browser created in 1996 by Oracle Corporation. It featured a multiple document interface and offered the possibility to act as a web server allowing users to host webpages on their computers. It pre-dated CSS and scripting, and was quickly discontinued.
